Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness in failing to inform applicant of Ethiopia's directive
Application_Facts: Applicant knew about Ethiopia's directive since October 2004; directive was publicly available
Decision_Outcome: No breach of procedural fairness occurred
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of visa application rejection
Defendant_Behavior: Immigration officer did not disclose Ethiopia's directive, but no obligation existed due to public availability
Grounds_for_Claim: Perceived availability of durable solutions in Ethiopia
Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness requires disclosure of extrinsic evidence, not public information
Procedural_Issue: Failure to notify applicant of publicly available government directive
Evidence_Used: Publicly available information on Ethiopia's directive
Legal_Provision_Cited: Section 72 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Application_Basis: Assessment of durable solution in country of origin
Relief_Sought: Certification of question and overturning of visa refusal
Governing_Rule: Officers must assess durable solutions; procedural fairness requires disclosure of non-public extrinsic evidence
Cause_Description: Rejection of permanent resident visa application due to perceived availability of durable solutions in Ethiopia
Evidence_Handling: No duty to disclose publicly available information
Evidence_Issues: No obligation to disclose public information
Legal_Provision: Section 72, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Directive was known and publicly accessible, so no procedural unfairness
Decision_Rationale: Officer acted reasonably based on facts; no breach of procedural fairness due to public nature of directive
Decision_Making_Body: Immigration officer, reviewed by Federal Court
Evidentiary_Issues: Distinction between public information and extrinsic evidence requiring disclosure
